headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. In terms of the order max, you noted them the technology have a great sound, you’re driving it. Can you give the split between capacity orders versus technology upgrade and also how do you see that percentage is shifting over the next couple
componenttext: Thank you. In terms of the order max, you noted them the technology have a great sound, you’re driving it. Can you give the split between capacity orders versus technology upgrade and also how do you see that percentage is shifting over the next couple of quarters and any particular segment tilting towards capacity?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, I think right now it’s really hard to tell exactly when you look at some of the systems that are placed and except for when you look at pure R&D, because we’re really obviously going to piloted their early part of the ramp and then the product g
componenttext: Yeah, I think right now it’s really hard to tell exactly when you look at some of the systems that are placed and except for when you look at pure R&D, because we’re really obviously going to piloted their early part of the ramp and then the product goes forward, but clearly we’re benefiting from the advanced technology nodes. I think the capacity buys are there, but if I had to do a rough split, just on top of my head, I’d say its 60-40 right now technology versus capacity and that that’ll probably trend and I think there is probably coming as we look forward and we think about some of the build outs that are going to happen and things like NAND where you see factors coming online over the next few years it’ll be more capacity oriented. But it’s really hard to say exactly what that split is, given the outside of the pure R&D technology buys. Is that makes sense?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you for taking my question. Could you guys explain maybe you did explain this on the call but I just didn’t hear, I joined a little bit late so I apologize, but could you explain why there is this re-divergence in terms of shipments in reve
componenttext:
Great. Thank you for taking my question. Could you guys explain maybe you did explain this on the call but I just didn’t hear, I joined a little bit late so I apologize, but could you explain why there is this re-divergence in terms of shipments in revenue, what in the product mix is driving that divergence or ability of recognized revenue? It seems like you’re building a decent amount of deferred revenue now.
And just second question, sort of a bigger picture question with still a lot of sort of new fab projects in the pipeline particularly for NAND in 2011. There is just sort of common perception that NAND is less CapEx intensive then DRAM per semi-cap equipment spending overall. I was wondering if that - the same case for inspection or metrology and whether or not inspection and metrology could actually see higher CapEx intensity with NAND compared to processing.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, I’ll take a part of that and let Mark deal with the divergence, your question on that. Really start with the second part of your question, capital intensity for NAND and DRAM. From our perspective, in a process control world, we are seeing new cha
componenttext:
Yeah, I’ll take a part of that and let Mark deal with the divergence, your question on that. Really start with the second part of your question, capital intensity for NAND and DRAM. From our perspective, in a process control world, we are seeing new challenges emerge in advanced design rolls on NAND that even our customers weren’t to wear out that as recently as three or six months ago challenges they’re having. So as a result, we are seeing increased activity and then increased in the process control percentage, the people are willing to invest and need to invest. So I think for us, NAND is going to be a healthy market as we go forward. That said, we still got a lot of work to do to execute on our strategy to support that.
And I don’t see, DRAM right now, I just think its overall there are many challenges associating with the technology but we start to see the overall activity level being as high for DRAM in general as we do for NAND. And Mark, can you split?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, let me just take a quick response to your question on the divergence between the shipment profile and the revenue profile. In the - first of all, it usually takes at least 90 days to turn shipments into revenue when you get into just passing the uni
componenttext: Yeah, let me just take a quick response to your question on the divergence between the shipment profile and the revenue profile. In the - first of all, it usually takes at least 90 days to turn shipments into revenue when you get into just passing the units along installing customer burn in and then final product acceptance. When we are moving in, let’s call it normal circumstances which isn’t that often as it turns out. You will see a 90-day turn of that or a little bit longer than 90-days. When you are in a step-up ramp like we’re in right now. It takes a little bit longer to turn that into revenue. I will say that however, in Q1 we actually revenued ahead of the prior quarter shipment. So we actually revenued 683 this quarter and we shipped 622 last quarter. So it can move back and forth. That won’t every quarter, but it will happen often just to let you know that it should vacillate at 90 or slightly greater than 90 days. I hope that responses to your question. And again, if we meet the shipment, the revenue will follow relatively shortly thereafter in the next couple of quarters.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Can I speak out one more question real quickly here? If you guys are going through a digesting face and you’re reflecting that in terms of your order guidance here in the December quarter coming off September, then in September why did metrology k
componenttext: Okay. Can I speak out one more question real quickly here? If you guys are going through a digesting face and you’re reflecting that in terms of your order guidance here in the December quarter coming off September, then in September why did metrology kind of hold fast at roughly the 130 million kind of range. I would have thought that if you’re starting to see the impact of capacity digestion, you would have seen metrology kind of downtick a little bit more than any other sector or division for you? Is there a reason for that?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Why September, I’m sorry, September metrology held in there, but overall we are down.
componenttext: Why September, I’m sorry, September metrology held in there, but overall we are down.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah. Why did metrology of all things hold a better in your order book compared to other segments when we’re going through a little bit of a capacity digestion as you indicated on the call?
componenttext: Yeah. Why did metrology of all things hold a better in your order book compared to other segments when we’re going through a little bit of a capacity digestion as you indicated on the call?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah. Well I think it’s a relative thing, right. I think it from our perspective, in that case there is the metrology that is turns out to be closer to turns business and has to do with supporting capacity where some of our inspection markets are longer
componenttext: Yeah. Well I think it’s a relative thing, right. I think it from our perspective, in that case there is the metrology that is turns out to be closer to turns business and has to do with supporting capacity where some of our inspection markets are longer in lead and therefore their timing is offset among different product lines. And so, just like process control buys probably had more turns in September, we have more turns in metrology. We also came off of a very strong market period in June for things like Reticle. So it’s a relative basis. Is that makes sense?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, absolutely. All right, thank you.
componenttext: Yeah, absolutely. All right, thank you.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: You got.
componenttext: You got.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Atif Malik from Morgan Stanley. Your line is now open.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Atif Malik from Morgan Stanley. Your line is now open.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, thanks for taking my questions. And a nice quarter, nice results. Mark, I have a question, as you think about EUV over the next couple of years, I mean I just want to know your operating expenses, R&D line, is there a reason to believe that and that c
componenttext: Hi, thanks for taking my questions. And a nice quarter, nice results. Mark, I have a question, as you think about EUV over the next couple of years, I mean I just want to know your operating expenses, R&D line, is there a reason to believe that and that can kind of creep up into next year because of EUV efforts or if you kind of stick with you actinic approach, you can move around R&D all those from different projects?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, it actually it’s an interesting observation, that take. It is possible that we could - we would have some upward pressure on the R&D line next year. Just as function of that total OpEx and as a function of revenue. And that could be just as a result
componenttext:
No, it actually it’s an interesting observation, that take. It is possible that we could - we would have some upward pressure on the R&D line next year. Just as function of that total OpEx and as a function of revenue. And that could be just as a result of the timing in new product introductions and certainly EUV is a big frontier for us on the R&D side. What you’ll see right now is, is that we previously laid out the model for KLA-Tencor. We’re experiencing levels of profitability in the current performance that we’re considerably ahead of where we were before.
And we believe moving into this period, if you - we spoke in, three or four years ago. We believe that we would get a 200 to 300 basis point improvement both from the operational improvement and some of the decisions that we made with respect offshore manufacturing and things like that, 200 to 300 basis point improvement in operating margin. We obviously are getting than that right now, but that is certainly partially a function of the actions we took, but it’s also partially a function of the timing of when new projects come on board and when new R&D hit and it’s possible we could experience some of that pressure as we look out into the first half of next year and certainly beyond that a little bit. But in the long run, we believe, we have obtained 200 to 300 solid basis points of improvement in the operating line.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just to be clear, the absolute dollars and even R&D I think could go higher but, does operating margins could still improve because of better supply chain or outflow?
componenttext: Okay. Just to be clear, the absolute dollars and even R&D I think could go higher but, does operating margins could still improve because of better supply chain or outflow?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don’t know if they would improve as a percentage from here. They should certainly go up as the revenue improves that we are experiencing a really high level of operating margin contribution right now is a function of revenue. And my point is, is that
componenttext: I don’t know if they would improve as a percentage from here. They should certainly go up as the revenue improves that we are experiencing a really high level of operating margin contribution right now is a function of revenue. And my point is, is that we maybe operating with a little bit of a tailwind in terms of complex R&D project, and if you look out farther than that, 452.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, just a follow-up, in your non-semi segment, can you - I know it’s a small contribution, but can you give some kind of order on where you saw the most trends in LED, solar or data storage?
componenttext: Got it. And then, just a follow-up, in your non-semi segment, can you - I know it’s a small contribution, but can you give some kind of order on where you saw the most trends in LED, solar or data storage?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, sure. We had a record quarter in solar for the September quarter that’s a small business but it did have a record quarter. I’d say the high brightness LED continues to look good and we continue to see growth there. Obviously there has been some
componenttext: Yeah, sure. We had a record quarter in solar for the September quarter that’s a small business but it did have a record quarter. I’d say the high brightness LED continues to look good and we continue to see growth there. Obviously there has been some softening in the disc space but we’re actually pretty well positioned with new products there. And then lastly, back in packaging we did see a little bit of softening and we expect that to continue reflecting some of the challenges in the back end on the short-term but we think that’ll recover as we go into next year.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And are there any big enough technology inflexion points in these markets this year or next year where liquidity could benefit or is it kind of a more of the old?
componenttext: And are there any big enough technology inflexion points in these markets this year or next year where liquidity could benefit or is it kind of a more of the old?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, there is definitely growth. I mean we’re seeing, and for us it’s a pretty good business segment. If you look overall we’re at a 200, $250 million run rate outside of course semi and we think the long-term growth trajectory of that stays that
componenttext: Yeah, there is definitely growth. I mean we’re seeing, and for us it’s a pretty good business segment. If you look overall we’re at a 200, $250 million run rate outside of course semi and we think the long-term growth trajectory of that stays that’s probably 20%. So the challenge is, of course that’s coming off is smaller base relative to the rest of our business. So there are definitely challenges in each of those markets, if you walk through and we’ve got products and we’ve got market position and the ability to invest and drive those as we go forward. So that’s part of our long-term growth plan, but relative to the other side of the business that remains reasonably small.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks.
componenttext: Thanks.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Your last question comes from Jagadish Iyer from Arete Research. Your line is now open.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, thanks for taking my question. Two questions, Rick. First question is that you’ve said about WFE being flat for all other. The question is that, given the mix is going to change between DRAM, NAND and logic and foundry, do you think that you can o
componenttext: Yeah, thanks for taking my question. Two questions, Rick. First question is that you’ve said about WFE being flat for all other. The question is that, given the mix is going to change between DRAM, NAND and logic and foundry, do you think that you can outgrow the WFE in ‘011 please?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We do. We think that again, if I go through it again, I think foundry is flattish, we think that logic is flattish, we think that the increases in the NAND space, having investments there and thus so in DRAM and based on our current positions and the inve
componenttext: We do. We think that again, if I go through it again, I think foundry is flattish, we think that logic is flattish, we think that the increases in the NAND space, having investments there and thus so in DRAM and based on our current positions and the investments that we’re making, certainly it's our plan to continue to grow. We do have the emerging markets as well. So yes, we believe we can continue our strategy of executing growth strategy like, it takes us faster than the overall industry performance.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. The second question is that, if the orders - if the order pass continues for the next two quarters or three quarters, do you think that you could sustain a gross margin of over 60% if assuming that revenue run rate is over 700 million?
componenttext: Okay. The second question is that, if the orders - if the order pass continues for the next two quarters or three quarters, do you think that you could sustain a gross margin of over 60% if assuming that revenue run rate is over 700 million?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean the answer is yes. If you look at our incremental gross margin, we guided up there, we guided 700, 740 and you can infer from our model that’s 60 to 70% incremental gross margin. We got a strong ratchet in that zone with gross margin. So we
componenttext: Yes. I mean the answer is yes. If you look at our incremental gross margin, we guided up there, we guided 700, 740 and you can infer from our model that’s 60 to 70% incremental gross margin. We got a strong ratchet in that zone with gross margin. So we’re in a strong position. But yeah, we believe that that’s what we’re committed to. We think it’s there and as long as revenue hangs in there, our growth, then we’re in great shape.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, one last question if I can squeeze it. Every one of your peers is talking about TFT and wafer-level packaging, can you help me find out, how much is scarlet tracking in terms of opportunities in wafer-level packaging maybe you can speak on that?
componenttext: Yeah, one last question if I can squeeze it. Every one of your peers is talking about TFT and wafer-level packaging, can you help me find out, how much is scarlet tracking in terms of opportunities in wafer-level packaging maybe you can speak on that?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Yeah, sure. We have plays on that. Obviously we’ve got some work going on in the back-end. We’ve got a very strong position on the businesses that we have there and we think for both wafer-level packaging and TFT we’ve got good opportunities and the potential to add but we want to make sure that those markets really materialize in a way that we would get a good return on those investments. So we’re tracking and then working closely that we believe we’re very well positioned for them.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Amanda and I will be your conference operator. I'd like to welcome everyone to the KLA-Tencor First Quarter fiscal 2011 Conference Call. I'd now like to turn the conference call over to Mr. Ed Lockwood of KLA-Tencor Investor Rel
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Amanda and I will be your conference operator. I'd like to welcome everyone to the KLA-Tencor First Quarter fiscal 2011 Conference Call. I'd now like to turn the conference call over to Mr. Ed Lockwood of KLA-Tencor Investor Relations. Mr. Lockwood, you may begin.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Amanda and we apologize for the technical difficulties this afternoon. Good afternoon, everyone and welcome to KLA-Tencor's First Quarter Fiscal Year 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on our call today are Rick Wallace, our President an
componenttext: Thank you, Amanda and we apologize for the technical difficulties this afternoon. Good afternoon, everyone and welcome to KLA-Tencor's First Quarter Fiscal Year 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on our call today are Rick Wallace, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Dentinger, our Chief Financial Officer. We're here today to discuss first quarter results for the period ended September 30, 2010. We released these results this afternoon at 1:15 p.m. Pacific Time. If you haven't seen the release, you can find it on our website at www.kla-tencor.com or call (408) 875-3600 to request a copy. The final cast of this call will be accessible on demand following its completion on the Investors section of our website. There, you'll also find the calendar of future investor events, presentations and conferences, as well as links to KLA-Tencor's SEC filings, including our annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended June 30, 2010, and our subsequently filed 10-Q reports. In those filings, you'll find descriptions of risk factors that could impact our future results. As you know, our future results are subject to risks. Any forward-looking statements, including those we make on this call today, are subject to those risks and KLA-Tencor cannot guarantee those forward-looking statements will come true. Our actual results may differ significantly from those projected in our forward-looking results. More information regarding factors that could cause those differences is contained in the filings we make with the SEC from time to time, including our fiscal year 2010 Form 10-K and our current reports on Form 8-K. We assume no obligation and do not intend to update those forward-looking statements. However, you can be reassured that any updates we do provide will be broadly disseminated and available over the web. With that, I'll turn the call over to Rick.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ed. Thank you all for joining us for our call today. I'm going to focus my commentary on the summary highlights of the September quarter and then provide guidance for December, then Mark is going to follow with a review of the financials. First of
componenttext:
Thanks, Ed. Thank you all for joining us for our call today. I'm going to focus my commentary on the summary highlights of the September quarter and then provide guidance for December, then Mark is going to follow with a review of the financials. First of all, there's no shortage of debate today as to the pace of the global economic recovery or the near-term direction in the semiconductor and the semiconductor equipment market. But KLA-Tencor September results demonstrate that process control adoption remains at a very high level. Our numbers also show the company's successfully executing on our long-term strategic objectives, delivering sustained market leadership, strong revenue growth, record margins, record earnings per share in the quarter. New bookings in the September quarter were $785 million. That's the third-highest level in the company's history. The high level of demand we're experiencing today is driven by the combination of strong adoption in the core markets and the healthy contribution from new markets in our services business. Revenues grew 22% sequentially to $682 million, significantly above the range of guidance and indicative of the high sense of urgency among our customers for getting our latest generation process technologies qualified and in place. Non-GAAP earnings was a record $0.99 per share in Q1, significantly above the guidance range of $0.80 to $0.88 per share. Underlying this outstanding financial performance in Q1 were record non-GAAP gross margins of 62% and record non-GAAP operating margins of 36%, with incremental margins coming in above our 60% to 70% target for gross margin and our 50% to 60% target for operating margin. And we ended the quarter with $1.5 billion in cash and investments and $1.4 billion in backlog. 
Now, in response to the high levels of demand we've been experiencing lately, we're focused on driving our operations to meet customer requirements and we are positioned for continued growth in shipments, revenue and earnings as we move forward. Our strong financial performance is a result of KLA-Tencor's technology and market leadership and it demonstrates the value our technology and services deliver in helping our customers execute their leading-edge technology roadmaps. It also helps us sustain the high level of R&D, which is essential to achieve our customer focus and growth strategies and provides the resources for us to deliver significant cash returns in the form of dividends and share repurchases. 
To that end, KLA-Tencor repurchased approximately 2 million shares of our common stock for approximately $62 million and paid cash dividends of approximately $42 million in the quarter. As you may recall, on July 13, we announced that our Board of Directors authorized an increase in the level of the quarterly dividend to $0.25 per share, which took us back with our first quarter dividend. That move reflects management and the board's confidence in the long-term outlook for the company, as well as the ongoing efforts to reward our shareholders for their continued investment. 
Turning now into some specifics of the demand picture, gross bookings in Q1 were $785 million, the third-highest in record for KLA-Tencor but below the midpoint of the range of guidance for the quarter. The first quarter end market picture was highlighted by a sustained strong demand from foundries, coming in at 44% of new orders in the September quarter. Our foundry customers are operating at high levels of capital intensity as they expand capacity to address the heightened competitive environment and increased business levels, driven by rapid proliferation of new tablet designs. Looking at the memory market, bookings for memory customers were 38% of the total in Q1. While DRAM pricing and PC demand have been declining of late, our leading-edge DRAM customers remain very profitable and are sustaining their investments to transition to the 4x nanometer and the 3X nanometer technology nodes. We also saw an increase in NAND equipment demand in Q1 to meet strong bit growth, driven by rapid adoption of smartphones and tablet PCs. Orders from NAND Flash customers grew to 72% of memory orders, with market leaders investing to ramp 30-nanometer and to qualify 20-nanometer technologies. Logic was 18% of bookings in September, driven by the continued migration to 22-nanometer. Now as you know, technology changes that enable Moore's Law are constant in our industry. But regardless of where we are in the industry cycle, chip manufacturers are continuously innovating to lower the cost of production and improve performance of their products and process control is essential to successful innovation. Although orders remained at a high level compared with historical averages, the downward trend in bookings in the first quarter, following an extended period of robust growth, was consistent with seasonality for KLA-Tencor. It's also indicative of a more cautious approach our customers have recently adopted with their capital spending budgets as weakening consumer PC demand and persistent uncertainty regarding the macroeconomy have impacted spending in the short term. However, overall semiconductor industry dynamics remain healthy and the importance of maintaining cost and performance leadership continues to drive investment at a high level. Current external market estimates have semiconductor revenues growing in the range of 30% in calendar 2010, with growth currently forecast in the midsingle digits for calendar 2011. Fab utilization also remains at a high level, and the WFE market is forecast to grow 120% in calendar 2010, with 2011 expected to be roughly flat year-over-year. We're tracking 13 new fab projects currently in development or scheduled to qualify over the next several quarters. 
The majority of semiconductor capital spending today is focused primarily on technology investment and not capacity. And that focus is a key driver of the high demand we're seeing in process control. And with the continued success of new products and sustained market leadership, coupled with our strong backlog and high-performance business model, KLA-Tencor is well-positioned to deliver outstanding revenue, profitability and earnings as we move ahead. 
Moving now to guidance. Gross bookings in December are projected to be flat to down 20%. We also expect continued revenue growth in strong margin performance, with December revenue expected to be in the range of $700 million to $740 million and non-GAAP earnings in the range of $1.00 to $1.10 per share. And with that, I'll turn the call over to Mark for his review of the numbers.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick. As most of you know, we present our income statement in 2 formats, one under U.S. GAAP and the other in a non-GAAP format, which excludes amortization and writedown of tangible assets associated with acquisition, expenses associated with our
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick. As most of you know, we present our income statement in 2 formats, one under U.S. GAAP and the other in a non-GAAP format, which excludes amortization and writedown of tangible assets associated with acquisition, expenses associated with our stock option-related litigation and certain costs and expenses, which are outside of our core operations, such as restructuring charges and unusual tax items. Our balance sheet and cash flow statements are presented in GAAP format only. Most of my prepared remarks and operations will refer to non-GAAP information but where I reference GAAP numbers, I'll make the distinction. A reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP income statement is attached to our press release and available on our website. The differences between this quarter's GAAP and non-GAAP numbers are: acquisition-related charges of $8 million before taxes or $0.03 a share after taxes; and a $9 million noncash tax charge due to a cumulative shortfall position in our employee stock activity. Removing this charge from GAAP earnings added about $0.06 per share to non-GAAP EPS. 
Following our record Q4, the Q1 new order total was $785 million, which was our third best quarter ever. Net orders were $787 million. Revenue and EPS for Q1 were above the top end of our guidance ranges we issued in July, as we processed the strong order pickup we experienced in the last few quarters. The regional distribution of new systems orders and the quarter-to-quarter change in distribution were as follows: the U.S. was 21% of new systems orders in Q1, down from 25% in the June quarter; Europe was 4% of new systems orders, down from 12% in Q4; Japan was 7%, down from 12% last quarter; Korea was 24%, up from 19% last quarter; Taiwan was 34%, up from 18% last quarter; and the rest of Asia was 10%, down from 14% in Q4. The Q1 distribution of new systems and services orders by product family and the quarter-to-quarter change in distribution was as follows: wafer inspection was 49% compared with 48% last quarter; radical inspection was 11%, down from 19% last quarter; metrology was 17%, up from 14% in prior quarter; solar, storage, high-brightness LED and other nonsemi was 6%, even with last quarter; and services were 17% of new orders in Q1, up from 13% last quarter. Foundry customers comprise 44% of semiconductor systems orders in Q1 versus 41% in Q4. Logic customers were 18% of systems orders in Q1 versus 21% in Q4 and memory system orders were 38% in Q1, even with last quarter. 67% of the semiconductor systems orders in Q1 were for 32-nanometer and below technology versus 41% in the June quarter. 
Looking forward, we expect that new orders for our fiscal Q2 will be within a range of flat to down 20% from Q1. Shipments in Q1, which include both system shipments and services revenue, were $677 million, up from $622 million last quarter. We added a little over $100 million to our backlog in Q1 and ended the quarter with $1.44 billion in total systems backlog. The backlog at September 30 included $337 million of revenue backlog for products that have been shipped and invoiced that have not yet been recognized as revenue and $1.1 billion in system orders that have not yet shipped. Systems revenue for Q1 was up 28% to $550 million compared with $430 million in Q4. Services revenue was $132 million in Q1, up slightly from $129 million in Q4. Our expectations for total revenue in Q1 is a range between $700 million and $740 million. 
Non-GAAP gross margin was 62% in the September quarter, up 2 percentage points from June. For Q2, we are modeling an incremental gross margin target roughly equal to our stated goal of 60% to 70%. Operating expenses were $180 million, up $15 million from the June quarter. About $3 million of the quarter-to-quarter increase resulted from giving our employees new iPad devices and grossing them up for taxes. Another $3 million of the increase was due to a Q4 credit in G&A expense for recovery of our claim arising from the Spansion bankruptcy, which did not repeat in Q1. We expect our non-GAAP operating expenses to increase slightly in Q2, in line with our stated incremental operating margin target of 50% to 60%. Other income and expense or OIE was a net $12 million expense in Q1, about $1 million higher than Q4. For modeling purposes, we expect OIE to be a net expense of approximately $11 million in Q2. In Q1, our non-GAAP income tax expense was $63 million or 27% pretax income versus $41 million in Q4, which was 25% of pretax income. The tax rate increase arose largely from a change in the distribution of earnings between the U.S. and lower tax in international operations. Non-GAAP net income was $169 million or $0.99 per share in Q1. If we exclude the iPad distribution expense and apply our modeled tax rate of 30%, our Q1 non-GAAP earnings per share would've been $0.96. At the revenue range I previously mentioned, we would expect our Q2 non-GAAP earnings to be somewhere between $1 and $1.10 per share, assuming a tax rate of 30%. Weighted average shares used to compute EPS in Q1 were 169.8 million versus 171.3 million in Q4. During Q1, we spent $62 million repurchasing about 2 million shares and as of September 30, we had approximately 3.2 million shares available under our current repurchase authorization. We anticipate continuing to repurchase shares in the December quarter. For guidance purposes, we are modeling an average share count of 169 million for Q2. 
Turning to the balance sheet, cash and investments ended the quarter at $1.5 billion, about even with the prior quarter end. Cash generated from operations was $96 million in Q1, compared with $83 million in Q4. The quarter-over-quarter increase in operating cash flow largely resulted because we had $133 million more in customer collections and we did not have to make a $26 million semiannual interest payment this quarter. These effects were partially offset by larger outlays, including annual bonus payments we made in September. Net accounts receivables ended the quarter at $500 million, up from $440 million at June 30, largely resulting from the $55 million increase in shipments from Q4 to Q1. DSOs were 67 days at September 30 versus 72 days at the end of June. All DSO figures are net of allowance for uncollectible accounts and factory. Net inventories increased by $62 million in June 30 and ended the quarter at $464 million. Inventory turnover baked upon GAAP cost of revenues was 2.3 turns in Q1, flat with Q4. Net capital expenditures were $11 million in Q1 versus $6 million in Q4. Total headcount at September 30 was 5,180, up from 4,989 at June 30. We expect our headcount will increase slightly during Q2. 
In summary, our guidance for Q2 is: new orders flat to down 20% from Q1; total revenue between $700 million and $740 million; non-GAAP EPS between $1 and $1.10, assuming the tax rate of 30% of the pretax income. This concludes our prepared remarks on the quarter. I will now turn the call back over to Ed to begin Q&A.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first part of that and I'll let Mark take the second part. As you know, we don't forecast that part, we don't guide bookings out into the next calendar year. But, I would say that the perspective right now is that calendar '11 looks to be fl
componenttext: I'll take the first part of that and I'll let Mark take the second part. As you know, we don't forecast that part, we don't guide bookings out into the next calendar year. But, I would say that the perspective right now is that calendar '11 looks to be flat with calendar '10, which of course was up significantly over '09. Whether that's back-end loaded or not, I think a lot of factors are at play. But if I model out the whole year, I think we're looking at a calendar '11 that we think is overall flat. We're tracking about 13 new projects and it really depends on the timing of when those projects get released to make an investment.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, with respect to your second question on what portion of the backlog is shippable over the next 6 months, we typically don't guide shipments. However, I do understand the nature of your question and because we're in a hyper ramp right now, I wil
componenttext: I'm sorry, with respect to your second question on what portion of the backlog is shippable over the next 6 months, we typically don't guide shipments. However, I do understand the nature of your question and because we're in a hyper ramp right now, I will tell you that our internal plan is to ship north of $800 million in the current quarter and repeat something like that coming out of Q2. So we would expect all of our backlog and maybe even a little bit more to try to ship out over the next 6 months. Those shipment figures do include, by the way, services revenue. We wouldn't typically guide this but I do understand the nature of your question.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Muse from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Muse from Barclays Capital.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm curious on the foundry side. I guess I love to hear kind of what you're seeing there from your customers and whether there was some pushouts there in the September quarter as to why new orders came in at the lower end of your guided range. And then, t
componenttext: I'm curious on the foundry side. I guess I love to hear kind of what you're seeing there from your customers and whether there was some pushouts there in the September quarter as to why new orders came in at the lower end of your guided range. And then, thinking a little bit longer-term into calendar '11, clearly very robust spend for your calendar '10. Can that repeat itself or has a lot of the spend in front end loaded? And I guess within that discussion, I'd love to hear your comments and thoughts around you spend for 28-nanometer and high k metal gate and how all in all the interplay for foundry spend should look as we move into calendar '11.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good questions. I think we did see a bit of softening. As we said, we're in the bottom part of the range for bookings for September, not really outside of normal for seasonality for us. But clearly, there's been a slight digestion period we think we're in
componenttext: Good questions. I think we did see a bit of softening. As we said, we're in the bottom part of the range for bookings for September, not really outside of normal for seasonality for us. But clearly, there's been a slight digestion period we think we're in right now across the industry and that includes the foundries. But there are several projects on the books and when we look out, there are major foundry players talking about increasing CapEx for calendar '11 and we see many projects outside of just the major players there. You go across the space and there's a lot of investment across foundries. Whether 2011 will repeat 2010, our current model is we see 2011 not only being flat but we see 2010 shaping up to be very hard to predict at this time where that will happen inside of the different segments. But we think foundry stays pretty strong, logic pretty steady and I think DRAM's probably remain soft, offset by NAND spending continuing. That's kind of how we see it.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: It's hard to predict that exactly, Jim but as you might imagine, we have guided up in revenue for next quarter and we would expect that we actually follow through with the shipment plan that we currently got in place, obviously the revenue would have to be increasing as we look at our fiscal Q3 as well. But it will follow in due course if we need to ship in place.

componenttext: If you look at your other guidance, the spread is about $160 million. What drives the low end and the upper end of the guidance?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Krish as you know, we've got big projects out there and whether or not they come through, I think you also know that from our perspective, we like to keep the range wide enough to not have any particular customer feel like they're going to be the di
componenttext: Well, Krish as you know, we've got big projects out there and whether or not they come through, I think you also know that from our perspective, we like to keep the range wide enough to not have any particular customer feel like they're going to be the difference between us making inside or outside the range. So, big lumpy deals. I do think in this environment, you end up with large deals happening and some of them come in and out and you certainly, with our position, with the backlog we've got, we don't want to be needy about the orders and so there are times where the negotiations get pretty deep into the quarter over price and so on. So we want to leave ourselves some wiggle room.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: My final question is late last year, you guys saw a nice tailwind from issues of the 4x nanometer. When the new entrants in foundry go to sub-4x, are you seeing similar kind of issues experiencing and how does that benefit you guys?
componenttext: My final question is late last year, you guys saw a nice tailwind from issues of the 4x nanometer. When the new entrants in foundry go to sub-4x, are you seeing similar kind of issues experiencing and how does that benefit you guys?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, definitely seeing issues across the board and we're hearing more and more challenges as people scale down and pushing really hard on our development projects. So what it's doing is we're engaging quite closely with customers and helping them come up
componenttext: Yes, definitely seeing issues across the board and we're hearing more and more challenges as people scale down and pushing really hard on our development projects. So what it's doing is we're engaging quite closely with customers and helping them come up with strategies to deal with the challenges of the advanced design rules. And at the same time, pushing very hard on getting the new products out that are going to help provide the capability to make the inspection and measurement necessary to support the advanced nodes. So no question that the challenges our customer face per yield are only increasing as we go forward.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Rick, if you look at your shipments and you just take 2010 relative to last year, it's up about 80% year-over-year and CapEx was up about 2x. Is that just shipment timing or is there some particular mix that's causing the shipments to sort of be more back end loaded in the year and even into Q1 for you than for your peers?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I think that we look at all those metrics and I think it is certainly true that we have some long lead items that take a little time for us to get out. I also think people get bookings were up more. We're up about 95% year-on-year if you count
componenttext: Yes, sure. I think that we look at all those metrics and I think it is certainly true that we have some long lead items that take a little time for us to get out. I also think people get bookings were up more. We're up about 95% year-on-year if you count the middle of the range and shipments will be lagging at about 80%. So we're certainly in line when we look at the bookings side but the shipments are a little bit lagging.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's really hard to separate. I think our market share ends up splitting more along specific customer lines. I have to think through how I tell you that up. I don't think there's a big difference frankly between NAND and DRAM for us in terms of share. It
componenttext: It's really hard to separate. I think our market share ends up splitting more along specific customer lines. I have to think through how I tell you that up. I don't think there's a big difference frankly between NAND and DRAM for us in terms of share. It kind of comes and goes over time. Our share ends up being pretty strong in some product lines and obviously not as strong in some others.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one quick follow up, what do you think the orders by customer type will be in the coming quarter?
componenttext: Just one quick follow up, what do you think the orders by customer type will be in the coming quarter?

componenttextpreview: Sure. We're looking forward to December, we see memory being about 36% of the overall orders. When we look at logic, see that about 10% and 54% out of foundry and 7% nonsemi.
componenttext: Sure. We're looking forward to December, we see memory being about 36% of the overall orders. When we look at logic, see that about 10% and 54% out of foundry and 7% nonsemi.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mahesh Sanganeria, RBC Capital Markets.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is KC calling for Mahesh. If you were to look at the range, would you say a lot of the uncertainty comes from the foundry, was this memory or the DRAM?
componenttext: This is KC calling for Mahesh. If you were to look at the range, would you say a lot of the uncertainty comes from the foundry, was this memory or the DRAM?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would attribute it to any type. I'd say the range is really more of a broader statement than a specific customer type.
componenttext: I would attribute it to any type. I'd say the range is really more of a broader statement than a specific customer type.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And when you look into next year, kind of flat CapEx, what are some of the products out there that concerns you, some of the concern?
componenttext: Okay. And when you look into next year, kind of flat CapEx, what are some of the products out there that concerns you, some of the concern?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our products or customer products?
componenttext: Our products or customer products?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Customers' products or projects.
componenttext: Customers' products or projects.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Oh, the projects that are out there, I see. Well, clearly in 2011, what we're counting on is continued investments as I said probably steady investment in logic. We think that there will be continued investment in foundry as the foundry competition really
componenttext: Oh, the projects that are out there, I see. Well, clearly in 2011, what we're counting on is continued investments as I said probably steady investment in logic. We think that there will be continued investment in foundry as the foundry competition really increases and actually gets more meaningful, more players investing. I think DRAM is likely to be a little bit soft and NAND would make that up. So if you take any of those and they don't hold, then that obviously would have a downward pressure. On the other hand, if we see more strength, let's say in the second half to our DRAM, then that could strengthen the position of the DRAM customers, driving more investment by them. So when we balance the whole thing, we do come up with a range where we see scenarios where it's up and we see scenarios where it's down and we end up coming out right in the middle.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mehdi Hosseini from Susquehanna.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mehdi Hosseini from Susquehanna.

componenttext: I'm sorry? For which quarter?

componenttext: For the September quarter.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: September, we don't break out individual divisions but we have to say that the nonsemi, which is where we lump the back end for us because it's non front end, non-WFE, was about 6% overall of the bookings and forecasted. Consistent with what it was in Jun
componenttext: September, we don't break out individual divisions but we have to say that the nonsemi, which is where we lump the back end for us because it's non front end, non-WFE, was about 6% overall of the bookings and forecasted. Consistent with what it was in June and forecasted in the December quarter to go into 7%. Now that includes back end test, high-brightness LED, solar and hard disk drive storage markets. So really, it's broader than what we get out of any one product division. But overall, consistent with what we saw in June.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then with equivalent lead time, in my opinion coming in and considering a flattish CapEx for next year, don't you think that your customers could wait until like Q2 to place the orders that would impact their production for the second half
componenttext: Understood. And then with equivalent lead time, in my opinion coming in and considering a flattish CapEx for next year, don't you think that your customers could wait until like Q2 to place the orders that would impact their production for the second half of next year?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Certainly. Yes, I think that the customer, if you think average lead down is on the order of 6 months for us, then certainly they could wait until June to get December shipments in December or fulfillment next calendar year. Not really a big change. I mea
componenttext: Certainly. Yes, I think that the customer, if you think average lead down is on the order of 6 months for us, then certainly they could wait until June to get December shipments in December or fulfillment next calendar year. Not really a big change. I mean what we've really been dealing with is ramping to meet the demand. I think with a lot of heroic effort, we're doing that and I think we'll be able to continue that. But yes, there's no question that you'd have to see bookings in the first half to support the second half numbers.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just very quickly, what should I think your booking guidance and your overall division is relative to some of the other front end equipment companies that have reported and have been relatively more constructive about the near-term booking momentum?
componenttext: And just very quickly, what should I think your booking guidance and your overall division is relative to some of the other front end equipment companies that have reported and have been relatively more constructive about the near-term booking momentum?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the biggest difference, I think we have with many of our peers is the backlog that we have and the strength that we had in prior quarters. For us, for example, the June quarter created a lot of backlog, which we're now working off. And so whe
componenttext: Yes, I think the biggest difference, I think we have with many of our peers is the backlog that we have and the strength that we had in prior quarters. For us, for example, the June quarter created a lot of backlog, which we're now working off. And so when we look at that, and even that, given that scenario, we added a backlog of over $100 million in the last quarter. So for us, we continue to drive the revenue growth and the earnings that go with that but we actually don't see that the bookings is willing to be at the same level for the December quarter. It will be slightly under but we'll still have a tremendous amount of backlog in the Q and be able to continue to drive earnings. I think a lot of the other businesses end up being more turns businesses, which cause them to perhaps burn off that backlog a lot faster.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of RE Chandra from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of RE Chandra from Deutsche Bank.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the order, technology upgrades were driving it. Can you give us capacity orders versus technology upgrades? And also how do you see that percentage of shifting over the next couple of quarters? And any particular segment towards capacity?
componenttext: In terms of the order, technology upgrades were driving it. Can you give us capacity orders versus technology upgrades? And also how do you see that percentage of shifting over the next couple of quarters? And any particular segment towards capacity?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think right now, it's really hard to tell exactly when you look at some of the systems that are in place, except for when you're looking at pure R&D. Because we're really obviously going to pilot or at the early part of the ramp and then the produc
componenttext: Yes, I think right now, it's really hard to tell exactly when you look at some of the systems that are in place, except for when you're looking at pure R&D. Because we're really obviously going to pilot or at the early part of the ramp and then the product goes forward. But clearly, we're benefiting from the Advanced Technology nodes. I think the capacity bias are there but if I had to do a rough split just off the top of my head, I'd say it's 60%, 40% right now technology versus capacity and that will probably trend. And I think there's probably more coming as we look forward and we think about some of the buildouts that are going to happen and things like NAND where you see factories coming online over the next few quarters that'll be more capacity oriented. But it's really hard to say exactly what that split is given outside of the pure R&D technology bias. Does that make sense?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. And one question on the December shipment split, how do you see that shaping up?
componenttext: Yes. And one question on the December shipment split, how do you see that shaping up?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The shipment split should approximately follow the bookings profile if you look to the prior quarter and this case maybe the prior quarter.
componenttext: The shipment split should approximately follow the bookings profile if you look to the prior quarter and this case maybe the prior quarter.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Sway from Oppenheimer and Co.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Sway from Oppenheimer and Co.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you guys explain, maybe you did explain this on the call but I just didn't here, I joined a little bit late so I apologize, but could you explain why there's this rediversion in terms of the shipments and revenue, what in the product mix is driving
componenttext: Could you guys explain, maybe you did explain this on the call but I just didn't here, I joined a little bit late so I apologize, but could you explain why there's this rediversion in terms of the shipments and revenue, what in the product mix is driving that divergence or ability to recognize revenue? Seems like you're building a decent amount of deferred revenue now. And just second question, sort of a bigger picture question with still a lot of sort of new fab projects in the pipeline, particularly for NAND in 2011, there's this sort of common protection that NAND is less CapEx-intensive than DRAM for semi-cap equipment spending overall? I was wondering if that's the same case for inspection on metrology and whether or not inspection and metrology could actually see higher CapEx intensity with NAND compared to processing?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take part of that and let Mark deal with the diversions, your questions on that. Let me start with the second part of your question, capital intensity for NAND and DRAM. From our perspective in the process control world, we are seeing new challe
componenttext: Yes, I'll take part of that and let Mark deal with the diversions, your questions on that. Let me start with the second part of your question, capital intensity for NAND and DRAM. From our perspective in the process control world, we are seeing new challenges emerge in advanced design growth on NAB that even our customers weren't aware of as recently as 3 or 6 months ago, challenges they're having. So as a result, we are seeing increased activity and an increase in the process control percentage that people are willing to invest and need to invest. So I think for us, NAND is going to be a healthy market as we go forward. That said, we still got a lot of work to do to execute on our strategy to support that. And I don't see -- DRAM right now, I just think it's overall, there are many challenges associated with the technology but we just don't see the overall activity level being as high for DRAM in general as we do for NAND.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just take a quick response to your question on the divergence between the shipment profile and the revenue profile. First of all, it usually takes at least 90 days to turn shipments into revenue when you get into just passing the units along, insta
componenttext: Let me just take a quick response to your question on the divergence between the shipment profile and the revenue profile. First of all, it usually takes at least 90 days to turn shipments into revenue when you get into just passing the units along, installing customer burn-in and then the product final acceptance. When we're moving in let's call it normal circumstances, which isn't that often as it turns out, you will see a 90-day turn of that or a little bit longer than 90 days. When you're in a stepup ramp like we're in right now, it takes a little bit longer to turn that into revenue. We'll say this however, in Q1, we actually revenued ahead of the prior quarter's shipments. So we actually revenued $683 million this quarter and we shipped $622 million last quarter. So it can move back and forth. That won't happen ever quarter but it will happen often enough just to let you know that it should vacillate at 90 or slightly greater than 90 days. I hope that's responsive of your question. And again, if we meet the shipping profile, the revenue will follow relatively shortly thereafter in the next couple of quarters.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can I sneak in one more question real quickly here? If you guys are going through a digestion phase and you're reflecting that in terms of your order guidance here in the December quarter, coming off of September, then in September, why didn't Metrology k
componenttext: Can I sneak in one more question real quickly here? If you guys are going through a digestion phase and you're reflecting that in terms of your order guidance here in the December quarter, coming off of September, then in September, why didn't Metrology kind of hold fast at roughly the $130 million kind of range? I would've thought that if you're starting to see the impact of capacity digestion, you would've seen Metrology kind of downtick a little bit more than any other sector or division for you. Is there a reason for that?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Why September -- I'm sorry, September Metrology held in there but overall, we were down?
componenttext: Why September -- I'm sorry, September Metrology held in there but overall, we were down?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, why did Metrology of all things hold up better in your order book compared to other segments when we're going through a little bit of a capacity digestion as you indicated on the call?
componenttext: Yes, why did Metrology of all things hold up better in your order book compared to other segments when we're going through a little bit of a capacity digestion as you indicated on the call?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I think it's a relative thing, right? I think from our perspective in that case, there's some Metrology that turns out to be closer to turns business and has to do with supporting capacity, where some of our inspection markets are longer lead a
componenttext: Yes. Well, I think it's a relative thing, right? I think from our perspective in that case, there's some Metrology that turns out to be closer to turns business and has to do with supporting capacity, where some of our inspection markets are longer lead and therefore, the timing is offset among different product lines. And so, just like process control guys probably had more terms of September, we had more turns in Metrology. We also came off of a very strong market period in June for things like reticle. So it's a relative basis. Does that make sense?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely.
componenttext: Yes, absolutely.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Atif Malik from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Atif Malik from Morgan Stanley.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, I have a question. As I think about EUV over the next couple of years, I just want to know your operating expense R&D line, is there a reason to believe that can kind of creep up into next year because of EUV efforts or if you're going to stick with
componenttext: Mark, I have a question. As I think about EUV over the next couple of years, I just want to know your operating expense R&D line, is there a reason to believe that can kind of creep up into next year because of EUV efforts or if you're going to stick with your approach, you can move around R&D from different projects?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, actually it's an interesting observation to take. It is possible that we would have some upward pressure on the R&D line next year just as a function of the total OpEx and as a function of revenue. And then that could be just as a result of the timing
componenttext: No, actually it's an interesting observation to take. It is possible that we would have some upward pressure on the R&D line next year just as a function of the total OpEx and as a function of revenue. And then that could be just as a result of the timing of new product introductions and certainly, EUV is a big frontier for us on the R&D side. What you'll see right now is that we previously laid out the model for KLA-Tencor, we're experiencing levels of profitability in the current performance that we're considerably ahead of where we were before. And we believe moving in to this period, when we spoke 3 or 4 years ago, we believe that we would get a 200 to 300 basis point improvement, both from the operational improvements and some of the decisions that we made with respect to offshore manufacturing and things like that. 200 to 300 basis point improvement in operating margin. We obviously are getting more than that right now. But that is certainly partially a function of the actions we took, but it's also partially a function of the timing of when new projects come on board and when new R&D hits. And it's possible we could experience some of that pressure as we look out into the first half of next year and certainly beyond that a little bit. But in the long run, we believe we have obtained 200 to 300 solid basis points of improvement in the operating line.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to be clear, the absolute dollars on EUV could go higher but the operating margin could still improve because of better supply channel?
componenttext: Just to be clear, the absolute dollars on EUV could go higher but the operating margin could still improve because of better supply channel?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know if they would improve as a percentage from here. They should certainly go up as the revenue improves. We are experiencing really high level of operating margin contribution right now as a function of revenue. And my point is that we maybe ope
componenttext: I don't know if they would improve as a percentage from here. They should certainly go up as the revenue improves. We are experiencing really high level of operating margin contribution right now as a function of revenue. And my point is that we maybe operating with a little bit of a tailwind in terms of complex R&D projects. And if you look out further than that 452.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then just a follow-up, on your nonsemi segments, can you -- I know it's a small contribution but can you give some kind of order on where you saw the most strength in LEDs or data storage?
componenttext: Then just a follow-up, on your nonsemi segments, can you -- I know it's a small contribution but can you give some kind of order on where you saw the most strength in LEDs or data storage?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. We had a record quarter on solar for the September quarter. It's a small business for us but it did have a record quarter. I'd say high brightness LED continues to look good and we continue to see growth there. Obviously, there's been some soft
componenttext: Yes, sure. We had a record quarter on solar for the September quarter. It's a small business for us but it did have a record quarter. I'd say high brightness LED continues to look good and we continue to see growth there. Obviously, there's been some softening in the disk space but we're actually pretty well-positioned with new products there. And then lastly, in back end packaging, we did see a little bit of softening and we expect that to continue reflecting some of the challenges in the back end on the short term. But we think that will recover as we go into next year.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Are there big enough technology inflection points in these markets this year or next year where PDC could benefit? Or is it kind of a more of the old?
componenttext: Are there big enough technology inflection points in these markets this year or next year where PDC could benefit? Or is it kind of a more of the old?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, there's definitely growth. I mean we're seeing and for us, it's a pretty good business segment if we look overall $200 million, $250 million outside of core semi and we think the long-term trajectory of that space is probably 20%. But the challenge is
componenttext: No, there's definitely growth. I mean we're seeing and for us, it's a pretty good business segment if we look overall $200 million, $250 million outside of core semi and we think the long-term trajectory of that space is probably 20%. But the challenge is of course it's coming off a smaller base relative to the rest of our business. But there are definitely challenges in each of those markets if you walk through them and we've got products and we've got market position and the ability to invest and drive those as we go forward. So it's part of our long-term growth plan but relative to the other side of the business, it remains reasonably small.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your last question comes from Jagadish Iyer from Arete Research.
componenttext: Your last question comes from Jagadish Iyer from Arete Research.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions, Rick. First question is that outside of WFE, the question is that given the mix is going to change between DRAM, NAND and Logic and Foundry, do you think that you can outgrow the WFE in '11?
componenttext: Two questions, Rick. First question is that outside of WFE, the question is that given the mix is going to change between DRAM, NAND and Logic and Foundry, do you think that you can outgrow the WFE in '11?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We do. We think that again, if I go through it again, I think foundry's flattish. We think that logic's flattish. We think there'll be increases in the NAND space, having investments there and less so in DRAM. And based on our current positions and invest
componenttext: We do. We think that again, if I go through it again, I think foundry's flattish. We think that logic's flattish. We think there'll be increases in the NAND space, having investments there and less so in DRAM. And based on our current positions and investments that we're making, certainly it's our plan to continue to grow. We do have the emerging markets as well. So yes, we believe we can continue our strategy of executing a growth strategy that takes us faster than the overall industry performance.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question is that if the order continues for the next 2 quarters or 3 quarters, do you think that you could sustain a gross margin of over 60% assuming the revenue run rate is over $700 million?
componenttext: Second question is that if the order continues for the next 2 quarters or 3 quarters, do you think that you could sustain a gross margin of over 60% assuming the revenue run rate is over $700 million?

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, yes. I mean the answer is yes if we look at our incremental gross margin, we've gotten it up there. We guided $700 million, $740 million and you can infer from our model the 60% to 70% incremental gross margin. We've got a strong reaction in that zo
componenttext: Well, yes. I mean the answer is yes if we look at our incremental gross margin, we've gotten it up there. We guided $700 million, $740 million and you can infer from our model the 60% to 70% incremental gross margin. We've got a strong reaction in that zone with gross margins. So we're in a strong position. But yes, we believe that that's what we're committed to. We think it's fair and as long as revenue hangs in there or grows, then we're in good shape.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Last question if I could squeeze in, I think one of your peers is talking about TFT and wafer-level packaging. Clearly tracking some opportunity with wafer level packaging.
componenttext: Last question if I could squeeze in, I think one of your peers is talking about TFT and wafer-level packaging. Clearly tracking some opportunity with wafer level packaging.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure we have plays in that. Obviously, we've got some work going on in the back end. We've got a very strong position with the businesses that we have there and we think for both wafer level packaging and TFT, we've got good opportunities and the pot
componenttext: Yes, sure we have plays in that. Obviously, we've got some work going on in the back end. We've got a very strong position with the businesses that we have there and we think for both wafer level packaging and TFT, we've got good opportunities and the potential to add. But we want to make sure that those markets really materialize in a way that we will get a good return on those investments. So we're tracking them and working closely but we believe we're very well-positioned for that.

headline: KLA-Tencor Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
